doc.ContractDescription: BOSTON CHILDREN'S MUSEUM (BCM), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE SMITHSONIAN ASTROPHYSICAL OBSERVATORY (SAO), PROPOSES TO CREATE "MY SKY," A TRAVELING EXHIBIT DESIGNED TO ENGAGE ADULTS AND CHILDREN AGES 5 - 10 IN BUILDING SKILLS AND DISCOVERING CONTENT FUNDAMENTAL TO LATER APPRECIATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF ASTRONOMICAL SCIENCE. THIS EXHIBIT WILL FOCUS ON INTERACTIVE EXPLORATIONS OF OBJECTS AND PHENOMENA VISIBLE IN THE SKY, ENCOURAGING FAMILIES TO "LOOK UP" NOT ONLY WHEN THEY VISIT THE EXHIBIT, BUT ALSO AS A PRACTICE THEY ADOPT IN THEIR EVERYDAY LIVES. BY EXPOSING YOUNG CHILDREN TO THE SCIENCE OF ASTRONOMY, THIS EXHIBIT EXPERIENCE WILL INTRODUCE FAMILY LEARNERS TO FOUNDATIONAL SCIENCE SKILLS THAT ARE AGE APPROPRIATE, CREATING A PLATFORM FOR SUCCESSFUL ELEMENTARY SCHOOL-AGE SCIENCE LEARNING AND A BASE FOR SCIENCE LITERACY. THE EXHIBIT WILL BE GEARED TOWARD "INFORMAL LEARNING" CENTERS, SUCH AS SMALL SCIENCE AND CHILDREN'S MUSEUMS, THAT ARE TYPICALLY UNDERSERVED BY OTHER SCIENCE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL CONNECT THE HOSTS OF THE EXHIBIT WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND NASA-SUPPORTED RESOURCES FOR PUBLIC PROGRAMS, SUCH AS THE MUSEUM ALLIANCE, THE NIGHT SKY NETWORK, SUN-EARTH DAY RESOURCES, AND AMAZING SPACE MATERIALS. PRINCIPAL COMPONENTS OF THE PROJECT WORK WILL INCLUDE: - A 700 SQUARE FOOT TRAVELING EXHIBITION DESIGNED FOR FAMILIES WITH YOUNG CHILDREN; - STRATEGIES FOR HOSTING PUBLIC PROGRAMS CONNECTED WITH THE EXHIBITION; - PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR STAFF AT HOST ORGANIZATIONS; AND - EVALUATION ASSESSING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE EXHIBITION AND ACCOMPANYING PROGRAMS AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS. THE PROJECT HAS THREE INTENDED AUDIENCES: YOUNG CHILDREN AGES 5 - 10; THEIR ADULT COMPANIONS; AND INFORMAL EDUCATORS WORKING AT HOST SITES FOR THE EXHIBITION. THE PROJECT WILL CONNECT TO SCIENCE AND EDUCATION RESOURCES FROM NASA'S PROGRAMS IN ASTROPHYSICS, HELIOPHYSICS, AND PLANETARY SCIENCE, AND IT WILL FOCUS ON TWO OF NASA'S MAJOR EDUCATION GOALS: ATTRACTING STUDENTS TO STEM CONTENT AND DISCIPLINES; AND ENGAGING AMERICANS IN NASA'S MISSION USING HANDS-ON INTERACTIVE EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES TO INCREASE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY LITERACY. ONE OF THE KEY ASSUMPTIONS OF THIS PROJECT IS THAT ADULT AND FAMILY ENGAGEMENT IN ELEMENTARY-AGE LEARNING IS CRITICAL FOR SUPPORT AND SUCCESS OF YOUNG STUDENTS IN STEM DISCIPLINES. WHILE THE CONTENT OF THE EXHIBIT WILL FOCUS ON PHENOMENA, IDENTIFICATION, AND INTERPRETATION OF VISIBLE OBJECTS IN THE SKY, THE ACTIVITIES WILL INTRODUCE AND REINFORCE FOUNDATIONAL SCIENCE SKILLS RELEVANT TO ALL STEM LEARNING: OBSERVING, COMPARING, MEASURING, DISCUSSING/REPORTING, AND EXPERIMENTING. WHILE MANY ADULTS MAY NOT FEEL PREPARED OR ABLE TO GUIDE LEARNING IN ASTRONOMY, THE EXHIBIT WILL ENGAGE ENTIRE FAMILIES IN HANDS-ON, GROUP LEARNING DESIGNED TO APPEAL EQUALLY TO ADULTS AND YOUNG CHILDREN. THE PROJECT TEAM BUILDS ON THE STRENGTHS OF BOTH PROJECT PARTNERS. BCM HAS BEEN A LEADER IN DEVELOPING FOUNDATIONAL SCIENCE EXHIBITS FOR ADULTS AND YOUNG CHILDREN FOR NEARLY 100 YEARS; THE SAO CONDUCTS RESEARCH RELATED TO CHILDREN'S SCIENTIFIC MISCONCEPTIONS AND HAS A STRONG RECORD OF EXHIBIT, MEDIA, AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT IN THE AREAS OF ASTRONOMY AND ASTROPHYSICS. IN ADDITION, BCM HAS AN EXCELLENT REPUTATION AS A PROVIDER OF TRAVELING EXHIBITIONS TO CHILDREN'S MUSEUMS AND OTHER CENTERS OF INFORMAL SCIENCE LEARNING NATIONWIDE. TOGETHER, THESE TWO INSTITUTIONS ARE PROPOSING A PROJECT TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR STEM LEARNING IN SMALL INFORMAL SCIENCE LEARNING CENTERS, REACHING AUDIENCES THAT ARE TYPICALLY UNDERSERVED, YET CRITICAL FOR IMPROVING THE SCIENCE SKILLS OF ELEMENTARY AGED AND OLDER CHILDREN.
doc.MajorAgency: MY SKY: A TRAVELING MUSEUM EXHIBIT, PROGRAM, AND T
doc.MajorFundingAgency: MY SKY: A TRAVELING MUSEUM EXHIBIT, PROGRAM, AND T

doc.ContractDescription: WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT COMPLEX INDICES OF REFRACTION OF DIFFERENT TYPES OF SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIALS FOR ACCURATE AEROSOL AND GAS RETRIEVALS BY SATELLITE INSTRUMENTATION, RECENT CLOSURE STUDIES HAVE EMPHASIZED THE HIGH PRIORITY OF OBTAINING IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE OF THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT OPTICAL PROPERTIES OF ATMOSPHERIC ORGANIC AEROSOLS. THIS PRIORITY IS MOTIVATED NOT ONLY BY THE NEED FOR ACCURATE RETRIEVALS OF AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH BUT ALSO BY THE NEED FOR ACCURATE RETRIEVALS OF ATMOSPHERIC GAS CONCENTRATIONS, WHICH MUST INCLUDE COMPENSATION FOR AEROSOL EXTINCTION. THE SUBMICRON FRACTION OF ATMOSPHERIC AEROSOLS, WHICH HAS A HIGHER MASS EXTINCTION EFFICIENCY FOR ULTRAVIOLET AND VISIBLE WAVELENGTHS THAN THE SUPERMICRON FRACTION, IS DOMINATED IN MANY REGIONS OF THE WORLD AND AT MANY TIMES BY SECONDARY ORGANIC AEROSOLS (SOA), YET THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT OPTICAL PROPERTIES OF THESE AEROSOLS ARE LITTLE INVESTIGATED. MOREOVER, THESE PROPERTIES DEPEND IN YET UNKNOWN WAYS ON THE MOLECULAR PRECURSOR TO THE SOA AND THE DOMINANT OXIDATION PATHWAYS LEADING TO SOA FORMATION. THE COMPLEX REFRACTIVE INDICES OF THE MATERIALS CONSTITUTING THE AEROSOLS ARE A FUNDAMENTAL FACTOR UNDERLYING THE OPTICAL PROPERTIES. IN ADDITION TO LIGHT SCATTERING, RECENT LABORATORY STUDIES AND ATMOSPHERIC OBSERVATIONS HAVE SHOWN THAT THESE AEROSOLS HAVE IMPORTANT ABSORPTIVE COMPONENTS UNDER SOME CIRCUMSTANCES. THE GOALS OF THE PROPOSED WORK ARE BOTH TO OBTAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE TARGETED AT REDUCING THE UNCERTAINTIES SURROUNDING THE FOREGOING ISSUES AND TO IMPLEMENT THIS NEW QUANTITATIVE INFORMATION IN UPDATED SATELLITE RETRIEVAL ALGORITHMS. THE ASSOCIATED OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1. TO MEASURE THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT COMPLEX REFRACTIVE INDICES OF SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIAL; 2. TO DETERMINE AND THEN TO MODEL THE CHEMICAL FACTORS THAT CONTROL VARIABILITY OF THE REFRACTIVE INDICES AMONG DIFFERENT TYPES OF SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIAL; AND 3. TO USE THE LABORATORY DATA OF PARTS 1 AND 2 TO TEST THE SENSITIVITIES OF SATELLITE RETRIEVAL ALGORITHMS TO VARIABLE ORGANIC AEROSOLS, WITH THE ULTIMATE AIM TO UPDATE THE ACCURACY OF THE OPERATIONAL ALGORITHMS. IN THE WORK TO BE PERFORMED, DIFFERENT TYPES OF SOA WILL BE PRODUCED IN THE HARVARD ENVIRONMENTAL CHAMBER (MARTIN, PI). GASEOUS PRECURSORS WILL REPRESENT BOTH BIOGENIC EMISSIONS (E.G., ISOPRENE, ALPHA-PINENE, BETA-CARYOPHYLLENE, LIMONENE, AND SO FORTH) AND ANTHROPOGENIC EMISSIONS (E.G., TOLUENE, XYLENES, AND SO FORTH). IN A SERIES OF PHOTO-OXIDATION EXPERIMENTS, NOX-, HO2-, AND RO2-DOMINANT REACTION REGIMES WILL BE PROBED BY ADJUSTING THE RELATIVE RATIOS OF NOX:HO2:RO2, AS MODELED BY THE MASTER CHEMICAL MECHANISM COUPLED TO A CONDENSATION MODEL (MCM-SIMPOL). DARK OZONOLYSIS EXPERIMENTS WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED. SECONDARY ORGANIC MATERIAL WILL BE DEPOSITED AS THIN FILMS ONTO SILICON SUBSTRATES, AND THE WAVELENGTH-DEPENDENT COMPLEX REFRACTIVE INDICES OF THE MATERIAL WILL BE MEASURED USING SPECTROSCOPIC ELLIPSOMETRY. THE THIN-FILM RESULTS WILL BE VALIDATED FOR THE AEROSOL BY USING CAVITY RING-DOWN SPECTROSCOPY AT A SINGLE WAVELENGTH WITH COLLABORATOR FREEDMAN. A RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL WILL EMPLOY THE REFRACTIVE INDICES TO SIMULATE SATELLITE RETRIEVALS AND THEREBY INVESTIGATE THE SENSITIVITIES OF ATMOSPHERIC GAS ABUNDANCE RETRIEVALS AT THE ULTRAVIOLET AND VISIBLE WAVELENGTHS TO AEROSOL PHYSICAL PROPERTIES (CHANCE, CO-PI). GASES WILL INCLUDE OZONE, SULFUR DIOXIDE, FORMALDEHYDE, NITROGEN DIOXIDE, AND GLYOXAL. IN COLLABORATION WITH TORRES, THE DATA SETS WILL ALSO BE TESTED FOR THEIR INFLUENCE ON OPERATIONAL SATELLITE RETRIEVAL SCHEMES, ESPECIALLY HOW THE NEW DATA SETS FOR ORGANIC AEROSOL CAN IMPROVE CLOSURE BETWEEN SATELLITE RETRIEVALS AND GROUND-BASED OBSERVATIONS. INITIAL TARGETS WILL BE THE OMAERUV AND OMAERO RETRIEVAL ALGORITHMS FOR AEROSOL OPTICAL DEPTH AND AEROSOL ABSORPTION OPTICAL DEPTH BASED ON THE TOP-OF-ATMOSPHERE REFLECTANCE MEASURED BY OMI. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL ASSIST NASA IN REALIZATION OF OBJECTIVE 2.1.1 OF ITS STRAT

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE THEORY TEAM OF SEAC4RS BY CONDUCTING QUICK-LOOK DATA ANALYSES AND DETAILED NEAR-REAL-TIME (NRT) MODELING IN THE FIELD. WE WILL USE FOR THAT PURPOSE A NESTED VERSION OF THE GLOBAL GEOS-CHEM CHEMICAL TRANSPORT MODEL (CTM) WITH 30 KM) HORIZONTAL RESOLUTION OVER THE SOUTHEAST ASIA DOMAIN TO BE COVERED BY THE AIRCRAFT. MODEL RESULTS WILL LAG REAL TIME BY LESS THAN 2 DAYS. THE GEOS-CHEM SIMULATION WILL INCLUDE DETAILED OXIDANT-AEROSOL CHEMISTRY, GREENHOUSE GASES (CO2, METHANE), AND VARIOUS CHEMICAL TRACERS (INCLUDING HCN, CH3CN) TO ENCOMPASS MOST OF THE SPECIES MEASURED BY THE AIRCRAFT. WE WILL USE OUR QUICK-LOOK ANALYSES AND NRT MODEL COMPARISONS TO OBSERVATIONS TO (1) GUIDE FLIGHT PLANNING, (2) PROVIDE FEEDBACK TO INSTRUMENT PIS ON THEIR DATA INCLUDING ANY APPARENT ANOMALIES, (3) MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF THE MISSION TOWARDS MEETING ITS OBJECTIVES, AND (4) CONTRIBUTE TO INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL REPORTING OF EMERGING RESULTS WHILE IN THE FIELD. OUR NRT MODEL DATA WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE FIELD DATA ARCHIVE. DURING THE SEAC4RS PRE-MISSION PHASE WE WILL CONDUCT GEOS-CHEM HINDCAST TRACER SIMULATIONS FOR JULY-SEPTEMBER 2005-2010 TO GUIDE MISSION PLANNING INCLUDING CHOICES OF PRIMARY AND SECONDARY FLIGHT BASES, DOMAIN TO BE COVERED, AND COORDINATION BETWEEN AIRCRAFT. OUR POST-MISSION DATA ANALYSIS WILL USE GEOS-CHEM TO INTEGRATE INFORMATION FROM THE DIFFERENT AIRCRAFT AND SATELLITE PLATFORMS DURING SEAC4RS, TOGETHER WITH ADDITIONAL INFORMATION FROM OZONESONDES AND SURFACE SITES, TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE REGIONAL AND GLOBAL IMPACTS OF SOUTHEAST ASIAN EMISSIONS ON TROPOSPHERIC COMPOSITION DURING THE SUMMER MONSOON.
doc.MajorAgency: SEAC4RS MISSION SUPPORT USING THE NESTED GEOS-CHEM
doc.MajorFundingAgency: SEAC4RS MISSION SUPPORT USING THE NESTED GEOS-CHEM

doc.ContractDescription: THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO TEST THE GIANT IMPACT HYPOTHESIS FOR THE ORIGIN OF THE MOON USING BOTH RADIOGENIC AND STABLE ISOTOPE CONSTRAINTS. WHILE DYNAMICAL MODELS OF THE GIANT IMPACT PREDICT THAT THE MOON WAS DERIVED PRIMARILY FROM COLLISION WITH A MARS-SIZED IMPACTOR, ISOTOPIC (E.G. O, CR, W, TI) DATA AVAILABLE SO FAR SUGGEST THAT MOON IS ISOTOPICALLY LIKE THE EARTH. TO EXPLAIN THIS DISCREPANCY, A POST-IMPACT MAGMA DISK ISOTOPIC EQUILIBRATION MODEL HAS BEEN PROPOSED WHICH, ALTHOUGH ATTRACTIVE, DOES NOT EXPLAIN ALL THE GEOCHEMICAL OBSERVATIONS. IN ADDITION, THE AGE OF THE MOON ALSO REMAINS CONTROVERSIAL, WITH ESTIMATES THAT RANGE FROM ~30 MYR TO>100 MYR AFTER THE FORMATION OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM. OUR MODELING OF THE HF-W SYSTEM DEMONSTRATES THAT DETERMINING THE AGE OF THE MOON IS FUNDAMENTAL FOR CONSTRAINING THE ACCRETION TIME SCALE IN THE INNER SOLAR SYSTEM. IN THIS PROPOSAL WE SHOW HOW WE CAN RESOLVE THE ABOVE ISSUES BY MEANS OF TWO MAJOR TASKS. TASK 1 IS TO MEASURE SI, CR, MG AND CA ISOTOPE COMPOSITIONS IN ORDER TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL ISOTOPIC UNIQUENESS OF THE MOON'S AND EARTH'S MANTLES COMPARED TO PRIMITIVE AND DIFFERENTIATED METEORITES, AS WELL AS TO UNDERSTAND THE ISOTOPIC EFFECTS OF CORE-MANTLE DIFFERENTIATION, MELT-VAPOR EXCHANGE AFTER THE GIANT IMPACT AND ETEROGENEITY IN THE SOLAR NEBULA. TASK 2 IS DESIGNED TO IMPROVE THE CONSTRAINTS ON THE AGE OF THE MOON BY USING THE RB-SR, SM-ND AND HF-W SYSTEMS IN THE OLDEST AVAILABLE LUNAR SAMPLES AND MARE BASALTS. THIS WILL RESOLVE WHETHER THE MOON-FORMING GIANT IMPACT EVENT WAS PART OF THE MAIN OLIGARCHIC ACCRETION PHASE OR IF, INSTEAD, WAS DUE TO SOME LATE VERY LOW PROBABILITY EVENT. THEREFORE, OUR PROPOSED ISOTOPIC MEASUREMENTS OF SI, CR, MG AND CA IN LUNAR SAMPLES, METEORITES AND TERRESTRIAL ROCKS WILL BE USED TO ANSWER THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS: (I) IS THE EARTH-MOON SYSTEM ISOTOPICALLY DIFFERENT FROM OTHER DIFFERENTIATED AND UNDIFFERENTIATED BODIES DUE TO EITHER CORE-FORMATION IN THE EARTH OR TO MELT-VAPOR FRACTIONATION IN THE LUNAR MAGMA DISK? (II) WHAT CONSTRAINTS DOES THE ISOTOPIC COMPOSITION OF THE EARTH'S MANTLE PLACE ON THE ORIGIN OF THE MOON? (III) WHAT IS THE AGE OF THE MOON? OUR PROPOSED RB-SR, SM-ND AND HF/W MEASUREMENTS OF THE OLDEST VAILABLE LUNAR ROCKS WILL PROVIDE MORE DEFINITIVE CONSTRAINTS ON THE AGE OF THE MOON. FURTHERMORE, OUR MEASUREMENTS WILL HELP UNDERSTAND GIANT PLANETARY COLLISIONS, WHICH WERE COMMON IN THE FIRST FEW MILLION YEAR OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM HISTORY, AND CONSTRAIN THE TIMING OF PLANETARY FORMATION. THIS IS IMPORTANT SINCE THE MOON-FORMING GIANT IMPACT WAS THE LAST BIG EVENT AT 1 AU AND THE ONLY GIANT IMPACT FOR WHICH WE POTENTIALLY HAVE SAMPLES. ONE OUTCOME IS THAT WE CAN CONFIRM THE PREDICTIONS OF THE GIANT IMPACT MODEL, AND RESOLVING ITS TIMING WILL PROVIDE AN IMPORTANT CONSTRAINT ON THE ACCRETION TIMESCALE OF THE TERRESTRIAL PLANET REGION. IF THE GIANT IMPACT MODEL FAILS THE ISOTOPIC TESTS, THEN (A) WE NEED TO CONSIDER OTHER OPTIONS SUCH AS JETTING OR FISSION OR (B) THAT THE SPH SIMULATIONS OF THE ORIGIN OF THE MOON ARE MISLEADING AND MUST BE REPLACED BY A BETTER TECHNIQUE FOR SIMULATING GIANT IMPACTS. WE HAVE ALL THE REQUIRED INSTRUMENTATION AND FACILITIES FOR MAKING THE PROPOSED MEASUREMENTS AND HAVE DEMONSTRATED THROUGH OUR PUBLICATIONS AND THIS PROPOSAL THAT WE CAN MAKE THE PROPOSED ISOTOPIC MEASUREMENTS WITH THE REQUIRED PRECISION AND ACCURACY NEEDED TO ACHIEVE OUR GOALS. THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL MAKE A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO THE MAJOR GOAL OF NASA'S COSMOCHEMISTRY PROGRAM: "INCREASE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE CHEMICAL ORIGIN OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM AND THE PROCESSES BY WHICH ITS PLANETS AND SMALL BODIES HAVE EVOLVED TO THEIR PRESENT STATES". OUR PROPOSED SAMPLE-FOCUSED WORK WILL ALSO HELP TO MAXIMIZE THE IMMEDIATE IMPACT OF NEW SAMPLES TO BE RETURNED FROM MOON, MARS, AND ASTEROIDS BY FUTURE NASA SPACE MISSIONS.
